Subjective: Spot on neck for 2 weeks; initially thought to be a wart, now unsure. Scabbing on and off. Itchy. No pain. Started after shaving and insect bite. Patient worried about malignancy, researched online, concerned about skin cancer. No fever, no weight loss. No similar spots elsewhere. Family history of skin issues (father's side: sun-related). No smoking or alcohol. Impact: No impact on work, sports, or sleep. Request: Wants spot removed, prefers freezing method.
Objective: Spot on neck: 0.5 cm, raised, pinkish-red, central red spot. No scab at present. No lymphadenopathy. No other skin lesions.
Assessment: Possible pyogenic granuloma or atypical mole. Ruled out: No signs of melanoma or other malignancy. No other abnormalities on exam.
Plan: Send photo to dermatologist via e-consultation.
Patient to call for advice on Friday.
Discuss treatment options with patient: freezing with liquid nitrogen, possible excision or scraping.
Arrange follow-up for knee pain if needed.
